benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/invoicePayments/{paymentId}/customFields - Retrieve payment custom fields

covered: Valid Request: Multiple successful retrieval scenarios cover default and explicit audit levels (NONE, FULL, MINIMAL) and general success cases.
Empty Response: Explicit test for payments with no custom fields returning an empty JSON array.
Query Parameters: Tests for valid audit values, malformed audit value (INVALID), extra/ignored parameters, and backward compatibility (audit=NONE) are present.
Authorization: Unauthorized scenarios covered (no token and invalid token -> HTTP 401).
Input Validation / Security: Invalid UUID format, SQL injection, XSS, trailing-space and special-character paymentId tests validate input sanitization and error handling.
Error Handling / Status Codes: Non-existent paymentId (404), invalid input (400), dependency/service down (502), service unavailable (503) are covered.
Performance / Scalability: Tests include large result set (1000 items), response-time threshold (500ms), concurrency under peak load, and retry after transient network failure.
Data Consistency & Regression: Tests for recently added custom field being visible and a regression case for prior 500-on-empty-array issue.
gaps: Pagination: No tests for pagination (limit/offset/page/continuation tokens) or server-side behavior when results exceed a single response — despite testing large result set, there is no verification of paging behavior.
Caching Behavior: No tests for cache-related headers (ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control) or conditional requests (If-None-Match / 304 Not Modified flows).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No explicit tests for rate limiting (429) or behavior under sustained high request rates; concurrent requests test exists but does not assert rate-limiting behavior.
Authorization nuance / Permissions: Tests cover unauthenticated (401) but not authorization/permission failures (403) or role-based access controls if applicable.
Response Headers and Content Negotiation: No explicit assertions for Content-Type header, charset, Vary, or Accept header handling.
Edge header/input flows: No tests for conditional requests, header tampering, or different auth schemes (e.g., session cookie vs token), and no tests for malformed Accept or Accept-Encoding headers.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: create a dataset large enough to force pagination and verify limit/offset or pagination tokens, correct total counts (if provided), and link/next headers or response shape for paginated responses.

Add caching tests: assert presence and correctness of Cache-Control, ETag or Last-Modified headers; include conditional requests using If-None-Match/If-Modified-Since and expect 304 where appropriate.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate sustained high request rates and verify correct 429 responses and Retry-After behavior, and how client should back off.
Add authorization/permission tests: include scenarios for authenticated but unauthorized users (403) and role-based restrictions if the API distinguishes permissions.
Assert response headers and content negotiation: explicitly check Content-Type and charset, and test Accept header variations to ensure JSON is returned or proper 406 behavior if not supported.

Clarify pagination vs large-result expectations in the API contract: if API is intended to return all items (no pagination), document and test maximum supported payloads and timeout/streaming behavior; otherwise implement and test paging parameters.
Extend security tests to header-based attacks and malformed headers, and include negative tests for unexpected Accept/Content-Type values to ensure robust input validation.
